text: Family Member: How soon can he get into the trial? Doctor: So what usually happens in general for clinical trials is that if you're interested in clinical trials, what I'll do is I'll contact the research nurse, and I'll say, you know, “Mr. H____ is interested in this clinical trial let's do it” because we have to make sure that your insurance allows you to be in clinical trials, and we have to confirm your eligibility and like for this, the MAP study- Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: -we would have you sign consent to do the testing to see the genotype first. So usually the time, from like, we're talking about it, and you are thinking about doing it to like, actually starting is a couple weeks. Family Member: Two to four. Doctor: It's always like, yeah, like, almost always within a month. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So, you know, probably, I mean, both of these probably two weeks. Patient: Did you get the results I emailed you. The DNA. Doctor: Yes. So, I got back the germline genetics testing. So this that this testing, well, do you remember? Tell me what you remember about that testing. The saliva testing that you did Patient: He was going to try to figure out um.. if this was hereditary or something. Doctor: Right, exactly. So that was negative for the, for the cancer causing gene. So that was negative. That is a different that's different than this.

Doctor: It's always like, yeah, like, almost always within a month. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So, you know, probably, I mean, both of these probably two weeks. Tell me what you remember about that testing. The saliva testing that you did Patient: He was going to try to figure out um.. if this was hereditary or something. Doctor: Right, exactly. So that was negative for the, for the cancer causing gene. So that was negative. That is a different that's different than this.

text: Patient: Because it was- it ran from here all the way down to my ankle. Yeah. Doctor: So you know, being on the blood thinner for at least three months is sort of the minimum that we have to do. Patient: Right. Doctor: And we could potentially stop it. Patient: Right. Doctor: And then you know, your body if your leg swells up again, that may tell us that we need to really use it for life. Patient: Right. Doctor: You know, the issue that you run the risk is if it does show up and we'll catch it early or you're aware of it and it pops up in your lung. Patient: Yes, that’s not good. Doctor: That's something that can be associated with pain or sudden death. Patient: Right. That's right. My sister in law died of that. Healthcare Professional: Oh, I’m so sorry.

text: Family Member: But during that whole two years you don’t really know what’s going on because you can’t measure it accurately right?

DOC Because the hormone therapy is suppressing what’s there and killing off ninety nine percent of it, then maybe not that last one percent, maybe, maybe not, the radiation does that. So we’re giving you all that we got. Um hum. Um hum. We want it all. Okay. Um and leakage issue. I think he’s doing pretty good, but how long does that typically take?

DOC About another month or so. A lot of times people get better suddenly. Doctor: So if you’re seeing some improvement it will just continue to get better. Patient: Yeah I was tell G___ you know it when I’m not as active there’s no problem but uh I started work last night so I can definitely feel… Doctor: That’s very common. Patient: Yeah, right. Doctor: You’re on the right track. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I bet within the month you’re maybe won’t need those pads anymore. Patient: Because the other thing too is uh I coach my daughters softball team so of course get that grade down, a bucket of ball (FAM Laughs) Doctor: So even a year or two from now it’s not gonna be – you don’t have as much resistance to outflow as you used to have. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But it should be enough that you would be dry almost all the time. Patient: Mm, hmm.

text: Patient: I was gonna say something oh that uh you know I had – I got some sleeping pills from a friend of mine. He’s a former nurse- Doctor: Okay. Patient: -okay so he done retired and stuff, but he gave me two sleeping pills that I took – and please believe me, I took with my OxyContin pill. I was like here – y’all just don’t know. I was feeling so good because the OxyContin was making me feel good, then I took a sleeping pill, I went right on to sleep. I slept the whole night. I didn’t wake up until the next morning. When I got out of bed this morning, I felt so good. Doctor: So did you ask him the name? Patient: Um ro-ro-roe or ro something like that, but it was – it – I mean I feel so good. I slept through the whole night. Doctor: Restoril, Restoril is a pill is a sleeping pill. Patient: Okay because they gave me that Ambien. I took one of them and a half of them, I slept two hours and I was back up again. Doctor: Okay so want to switch the Ambien to the Restoril? Patient: Yeah I mean if it’s gonna make me sleep through the whole night to the next morning. I’d love that because- Doctor: Okay. Patient: -I when I get my sleep I’m more active. See that’s why I lost a lot of weight because of that. Doctor: Alright so I can make one change at a time. Which one do you want to go? Do you want to go with the Oxycodone change, the Percocet, or what do you want to do?

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
